body:
@tqchen, so you suggesting that if a certain variable is fed into multiple nodes, the code that handles aggregations automatically marks it as `kWriteTo`, because it will compute an aggregation?

So the fix would be to change that code to recognize that all the nodes that the variable is fed into do not propagate gradient back? Do you know where the code that handles aggregations is located?

Try this:
Update mxnet, follow the guide for Android (you can skip OpenBLAS install) and run
`make MIN=1 ANDROID=1`

However it will be very slow, sometimes 10x-20x slower w.r.t. OpenBLAS version.

Just use bucketing will work
Don't use the launch script if you are using single machine. It will start another process and that's why you are not seeing any output from nvprof

just submitted a support ticket to my domain register. The reason was that, the register sent me an cancellation email yesterday (Sunday) due to some unknown reasons from their review team, and the email dropped to my spam folder, so I didn't see it. Sorry about that.

Meanwhile, we might want to think of moving to `dmlc.ai` which is a paid domain with better customer service. Currently `dmlc.ai` is redirecting to `dmlc.ml`. Any ideas please @tqchen @mli @antinucleon ?

dmlc.ml is good enough for now. one issue is that the response of
connecting to dmlc.ml is slow in last month, probably due to incorrect dns
or other setting?

The testing need too much time. Maybe we need to use another sets of parameters, or just skip the RNN example.

A question came into my mind, when I was going through this post again. In the case of aysnc execution, we say that: 

> While running exe2, if it is not blocked manually, exe1 is able to run on next batch

But in order to correctly run on the next batch, the parameters need to be updated with the SGD calculations. So, if exe1 runs on the next batch while exe2 is processing the previous one, exe1 will calculate outdated forward pass results. exe1 should wait for the SGD calculation anyhow, which is dependent on exe2's forward-backward calculations. So, everything will be placed in a queue, more or less. How exactly does help async scheduling in that case?
In this case, while running backprop in exe1 (bottom), it is able to run SGD update in exe2(top). So once full backprop is done, full update is almost done, then we are ready to run next batch.
I changed the parameter `num.round` smalller to reduce the running time.
LGTM
e, it's a bit difficult...
non deterministic as in random error or slight difference between runs?
Yes it indeed is. It especially slows you down if you are in a different timezone, than the majority of people with merge rights.
@piiswrong slight difference between runs. Using  NaiveEngine won't have this problem, so it may be the problem of synchronization
Are you sure the diff is from this layer? Is it's input deterministic?

@piiswrong Yes, I replaced the self define loss layer with softmaxoutput, the results between runs  are the same. What't more, if the input is non deterministic, I won't get  the same value with NaiveEngine

can you verify that the input to your loss layer is the same by binding it as  a additional output?
If it's indeed the same. Try a simpler kernel to see which operation in your kernel is causing this.

The reason why the mnist test failed is that I modified `mx.io.arrayiter` to let label support multi-dimension and made a mistake.

I'm sorry and have fixed the bug.
This situation will also occur when you train on GPU 4, but there is only one gpu in another machine. So I suggest to copy all the content to cpu, and then save it.

Since there is not enough examples on variable shape input in Module API, we think we should stick to the old model API for now. The detection example rebinds in each iteration so it is not intuitively to use the module API.
Or we may add `ctx` params in load function. By default load to CPU.
The results are verified, and the acceleration ratio is provided in readme
Variable shape is implemented in bucketing module

The idea of bucket seems to me a way of padding inputs to predefined bucket shapes or symbols in order to share memory and save time. However, in the fully convolutional network case, it is undefined how to find "buckets" for variable image size. A naive way would choose some scales and size as buckets but padding data with a lot of zeros may result in inferior performance.

@piiswrong rebased

Thanks! That is related. I've been basing my model on the one in that example. In fact, I basically just copied it and changed the python conventions to R. 

Here's the issue I'm having: when I get to the 

```
total_filters = num_filter * length(filter_list)
concat = mx.symbol.Concat(pooled_outputs, num.args=length(filter_list), dim=1)
h_pool = mx.symbol.Reshape(data=concat, target_shape=c(batch_size, total_filters))
```

The last line, using Reshape(), gives me an error, `from.shape() == to->shape() operands shape mismatch` I've tried changing the arguments to the Reshape() and nothing works.

If, instead, I use the `mx.symbol.Flatten(concat)` (as in the MNIST examples), the model will run, but the results are also way off. But that could just be my data or the untuned model parameters.

I can't seem to find what "Flatten" is doing, or if it's accomplishing what the text classification example was trying to do with Reshape(). If not, how do I use Reshape() correctly? 

If it's helpful, here's the model code. The input data is an array, 50 (sentence length) by 300 (word2vec embeddings) by 1 (channel) by 30000 (training samples). The target is dichotomous. 

```
# fit the CNN
library(mxnet)
pooled_outputs = c()
sent_length = 50
data = mx.symbol.Variable("data")
filter_list = c(3,4,5); 
batch_size=100; 
num_filter=100
for(f in 1:length(filter_list))
{
  convi = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=c(filter_list[f],300),num_filter=num_filter)
  relui = mx.symbol.Activation(data=convi, act_type='relu')
  pooli = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=relui, pool_type='max', kernel=c((sent_length-filter_list[f]+1),1))
  pooled_outputs = c(pooled_outputs,pooli)
}
total_filters = num_filter * length(filter_list)
concat = mx.symbol.Concat(pooled_outputs, num.args=length(filter_list), dim=1)
#h_pool = mx.symbol.Reshape(data=concat, target_shape=c(100, total_filters)) # Doesn't work?
h_pool = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=concat)
h_drop = mx.symbol.Dropout(data=h_pool,p=0.2)
fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=h_drop, num_hidden=100)
act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(fc1,act_type='sigmoid')
drop1 = mx.symbol.Dropout(act1,p=0.2)
fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(drop1, num_hidden=2)
# softmax output
sm = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc2, name='softmax')
mx.set.seed(0)
devices=mx.cpu()
model = mx.model.FeedForward.create(sm, X=x, 
                                    y=as.numeric(as.factor(subideoForCNN)),
                                    ctx=devices,num.round=200,array.batch.size=batch_size,
                                    learning.rate=0.005,momentum=0.9,
                                    wd=0.00001,eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy,
                                    initializer=mx.init.uniform(0.01),
                                    lr_scheduler=FactorScheduler(step=batch_size*50, factor = 0.95),
                                    eval.data=list(data=xt,
                                                   label=as.numeric(as.factor(subideoTest))))
```

With #2366 and a batch size of 64, I got an accuracy of 0.939704 after 200 epochs on 2 GPUs.
Note, **the accuracy is strongly affected by the batch size**, the more GPU you use, the smaller batch size should be.
See https://gist.github.com/Answeror/f9160145e1c64bb509f52c00014bdb77#file-resnet-dual-gpu-log for the full log.

The code looks basically like this:

``` Python
    X_train = TrainingGenerator(train_sequence, train_dnases, train_contacts, train_regions, window, data_shapes, coord, batch_size)
    X_eval = ValidationGenerator(valid_sequence, valid_dnases, valid_contacts, valid_regions, window, data_shapes, coord, batch_size)

    model = Rambutan( use_coord=coord,
                      ctx=[mx.gpu(0), mx.gpu(1), mx.gpu(2), mx.gpu(3)], 
                      epoch_size=5000,
                      num_epoch=1,
                      learning_rate=0.01,
                      wd=0.000,
                      optimizer='adam'
                    )

    model.fit( X=X_train,
               eval_metric=['acc', roc_auc_score],
               batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size)
            )

    y = model.predict(X_eval)[:,1]
    numpy.save('rambutan-q={}.npy'.format(q), y)
```

If I put eval_data = X_eval into the fit step, it seems to work. The issue is the predict step.

I am also having this issue. As the previous user notes, editing the .prototxt file and removing the `global_pooling` under pool10 and replacing with `kernel_size: 13` (for the specific case of the SqueezeNet) works wonders. I feel that this issue should be able to be resolved by adding support for global pooling.

Hi, one way to do this is to use the intermediate API of module and imperative scheduling. See [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/module/python_loss.py) for example of scheduling a standard module and a pure Python module together. 

Another way is to use a fixed number of layers for computing, but for each time, randomly sample some layers from the pool of a large number of layers, and assign the weights (by pointer assignment, which should be fast) to the layers in the computing graph (who always has a fixed number of layers and the architecture does not change).

The input to the loss layer is definitely the same. I extract the self-defined kernels codes, and do a unit-test, they have no problem.
 I find two ways to eliminate  this no deterministic phenomenon. The First is as I mentioned above, using the naive engine. Another way  is setting the MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS to 1. I still can't figure out why it happens. Is there any thing should be noticed when writing a self defined kernel?

Thanks for all the answers. I have yet another (hopefully final) question: Let's say we have an input of 100  samples. And let's assume that I have divided them main network into two layers: The first layer, containing first partial network, F1, is bound to exe1. After exe1 runs on the batch, its output is analyzed and we decide 60 of the output samples will be processed by network F2, represented by exe2 and the remanining 40 will be processed by another network F3, represented by exe3. 

With pseudocode:
`exe1.forward()`
`#Determine which samples go into exe2 and exe3`
`exe2Input = getExe2Input(exe1.outputs)`
`exe3Input = getExe3Input(exe1.outputs)`
`# copy exe2Input and exe3Input into input buffers for exe2 and exe3`
`exe2.forward()`
`exe3.forward()`
`exe2.backward()`
`exe3.backward()`
`#Reshape and pad exe2.grad_dict["data"] into grad2`
`#Reshape and pad exe3.grad_dict["data"] into grad3`
`exe1.backward([grad2])`
`exe1.backward([grad3])`

If 60 samples go into exe2 and 40 into exe3, the last two lines will execute 100 redundant operations in total since grad2 will have 40 and grad3 will have 60 zero entries as the result of padding.

My question is, how can we avoid these redundant backward calculations? A naive solution would be rebind two executors, exe1_2 and exe1_3 (encapsulating F1) according to 60 and 40 sample sizes, but in order to calculate gradients with them, we need to execute forward passes as `exe1_2.forward()` and `exe1_3.forward()`. So, for the first layer we execute two forward calculations (the other one is the first `exe1.forward()`). This again introduces redundancy. When we call the first forward() on exe1, actually we calculate all the needed intermediate results for the backward calculations for all 100 samples. To take it short: Is there any way to copy the results of the first `exe1.forward()` into both exe1_2 and exe1_3, such that we can directly call backward() on them, without redundantly executing forward passes?
